replies.text: Enphase is good Anyone who believes in solar, EV charging themes, and power hungry data centers and A.I. needing renewable power, can look at ENPH. It generally has shown negative beta, and the stock seems to make random, out of sync moves compared to market. Today was an exception. Has shown strong buy volume spikes around 80.

I am heavily invested in ENPH. Here is what I know.. 1. ENPH is mostly residential. 65 of the revenue in the US and the rest is from EU. Theyre expanding in other parts of the world but revenue at the moment is still very low. They have recently introduced products for commercial as well, but revenue is still very negligible. 2. I am not certain about FSLR. They produce panels especially for utility scale. With the recent tariffs on panels imported from China, they seem to be more in play. 3. ENPH has a decent moat on the microinvertor tech, but their strength is their ecosystem invertors, battery, EV chargers and energy management last two still fairly new and I anticipate at some point in the future, theyll charge customers a monthly fee as they would help the customer save money on Energy management because of dynamic tariffs in various geos a few years away though. I havent invested in FSLR but I am definitely interested in it.
After reading this article, I decided to sit on the side lines and watch this time around. Just too many uncertainties. Good Luck.
RemindMe! 1 week

Havent invested in them but I have traded both. Ive noticed that while both are very interest rate sensitive FSLR seems to hold up better when there is bad interest rates news. Which makes me think they will do well in favorable interest rate environment Seems they still able to show some earnings in a bad environment for their industry. ENPH less so. They are both best in class in the industry but if I had to pick one for long term it would be FSLR but I havent done a deep dive into their fundamentals. I expect both will pop on cuts but I think FSLR will maintain the pop where ENPH will not because of there is a lot of people underwater on ENPH.

FSLR makes panels for utility scale solar. They dont do any residential. They are the industry leader in that segment in the US and have a multiyear backlog of orders. Their narrow moat is a proprietary panel design and manufacturing process that reduces the cost per watt and is much less energy intensive to build. Chinese manufacturers are heavily subsidized by the state, and are a risk to FSLRs moat. Current protectionist policies are keeping them from flooding the market and crashing prices, but if policy changes it could wipe out their moat.
The case against ENPH is that they dont really have any moat. Anyone can make what they make.

I would not equate all those things with Enphase. Residential, charging, storage yes. Utility level power including data centers is First solar. Im long Enphase. Both are the only investable solar companies to me.

I will be messaging you in 7 days on 20240815 165340 UTC to remind you of this link CLICK THIS LINK to send a PM to also be reminded and to reduce spam. Parent commenter can delete this message to hide from others. Info Reminders

I would look closer in this cycle. Enphase continues to turn organic profits despite being residential. First solar percentage profit above enphase is reliant on the IRA tax credits. However I agree long term thesis that first solar would be less affected by interest rate increases as they become more integrated with utilities.

So, if SBUX announced earnings last week, how come they are still to be announced now? I dont know so im just asking plus they chose not to forecast 25? From their own webiste? For the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2024, global comparable store sales declined 7, and consolidated net revenues declined 3 to 9.1 billion, or a 3 decline on a constant currency basis. GAAP earnings per share is 0.80, down 25 over prior year. NonGAAP earnings per share is also 0.80, declining 24 on a constant currency basis. The companys results were primarily driven by softness in North Americas revenues in the quarter, specifically a 6 decline in U.S. comparable store sales, driven by a 10 decline in comparable transactions, partially offset by a 4 increase in average ticket. The accelerated investments in an expanded range of product offerings coupled with more frequent inapp promotions and integrated marketing to entice frequency across the customer base did not improve customer behaviors, specifically traffic across both Starbucks Rewards and nonSR customer segments, resulting in lowerthanexpected performance. Additionally, China comparable store sales declined 14, driven by an 8 decline in average ticket compounded by a 6 decline in comparable transactions, weighed down by intensified competition and a soft macro environment that impacted consumer spending. Despite our heightened investments, we were unable to change the trajectory of our traffic decline, resulting in pressures in both our topline and bottomline. While our efficiency efforts continued to produce according to plan, they were not enough to outpace the impact of the decline in traffic, commented Rachel Ruggeri, chief financial officer. We are developing a plan to turn around our business, but it will take time. We want to amplify our confidence in the business, and provide some certainty as we drive our turnaround. For that reason, we have increased our dividend Our fourth quarter performance makes it clear that we need to fundamentally change our strategy so we can get back to growth and thats exactly what we are doing with our Back to Starbucks plan, commented Brian Niccol, chairman and chief executive officer.

For years, I trusted traditional bankWallstreet Bankswhere I kept a considerable amount of 225,000 in their savings account. The bank often referred me as a Elite ,Highvalue , Premier Customer. Those words sparkled in my mind, evoking images of exclusivity and prestige. Yet, I received monthly interest of Four dollar 87 cents. Being in Silicon Valley and driven by curiosity of Fintech banks, I moved all my money to Fintech bank, they just called me by my Name, Initially, the simplicity without the title felt underwhelming, but the moment I saw the first interest paymenta staggering of 1,000 per month a meaningful returns. From Four dollar 87 cents a month from traditional bank to 1000 a month from Fintech bank, realized how traditional banks eat our money by throwing a prestigious title on US... Sometimes, it takes a little time to see the truth beneath the surface

The key to buying options is understanding how fast money can disappear with time decay. If youre buying calls. The price must move up faster than what the momentum of the stock was when you bought it. The opposite is true for puts. Almost always avoid buying any options within the first hour or two. Unless its a rare circumstance like Tesla was opening morning after earnings. Options value time decay increases rapidly the closer you get to the date of expiration. My advice to you would be to buy calls a month to three months out the day before earnings, so even if its not great, theres still time for it to recover.

As of September 2024, the West continues to impose heavy sanctions and restrictions on imports of many Russian goods, particularly in the wake of the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. However, some Western countries still import specific Russian products, though in significantly reduced volumes compared to pre2022 levels. Key imports that continue to flow from Russia to Europe and the U.S. include 1. Energy Products Although many European countries have drastically cut their dependence on Russian natural gas and oil, certain imports like liquefied natural gas LNG still persist, albeit at reduced levels. 2. Metals Russian aluminum and derivative products are still imported, though the U.S. imposes a 200 tariff on aluminum and derivative products smelted or cast in Russia, and similar measures are applied to steel and other metals. 3. NonEnergy Commodities Certain agricultural products like fertilizers continue to be imported into Europe due to their critical role in food production. Overall, the proportion of Russian goods imported by the West has significantly decreased due to sanctions, tariffs, and a broader pivot away from reliance on Russian supply chains. The most prominent exceptions are energy and select raw materials, often subject to very high tariffs or specific exclusions. Admiteddly, severed all ties is a bit excessive, severed most of them is more accurate.

This is only true for home solutions, which is more politically sensitive. For utility level solar, solar farms are proving themselves as reliable and extremely low upkeep cost at the same time as manufacturing them is getting incredibly cheap. Global installed solar capacity has been growing literally exponentially, doubling every 3 years. The more panels that are manufactured, the more economies of scale kick in, and it becomes even cheaper to make, making even not so sunny places cost effective for solar, even in the absence of sufficient grid level storage mechanisms. Which are also developing fast, just not exponentially like solar. In 10 years, solar will be the largest source of electrical power on the planet. Energy produced by them will cost less than half as much as the cheapest electricity to produce today. No politician can deny reality in the long term, as republicans are finding out as people whose homes are destroyed by flooding in the SE US are more likely to believe in climate change regardless of political leaning. Solar is going to be a huge part of the future, and most people dont see it yet. Of course having said this, many of the factors I just named mean that actual margins in the industry will probably go pretty low in the long term, and its going to be essentially impossible to establish a moat. So still hard to pick individual winners.

The challenge with the FSLR business is that it is "lumpy" with respect to MW sold. Hence, the reduction in 2024 EPS by ~6% (vs. last guidance). I don't see more than a 6% hit on the stock price between now through the weekend (~$187/share).I continue to think that many traders will want to head to the sidelines until Nov 8 given the expected volatility. Smart investors with a one-year outlook can take advantage here. And jump in on Nov 5. This is because the option market is predicting a lot of volatility between now through Nov 8: plus / minus 11% from current level of ~$192).However, I think that the political risk of a Trump win and GOP Senate control is overstated. Do your homework: the majority of the IRA solar tax credits are going to Red States. Tens of billions of dollars have been invested across Texas, Florida, Alabama, and Louisiana on the basis of the IRA tax credits. And tens of thousands of jobs in Red states are counting on this. There's no way that Congress is going to roll back solar tax subsidies. Additionally, both Harris and Trump will have tariffs that benefit FSLR (as a local manufacturer). And if Trump can pass a 15% corporate tax on local manufacturers, that's another tail-wind for FSLR.Good luck to all !

I got distracted by the big drop yesterday and jumped in on the tail to lose nearly 2% before really pulling apart the financials after the fact. FSLR has an ASP of over 30c / W for fairly low performance panels i.e. 18%. I just bought 30kW retail over in Europe for 10c / W 21% efficiency. This is European manufactured panels with obviously Chinese cells that cost 3c / W. That is 1/3rd the ASP of FSLR and I paid retail. FSLR only works in the US due to 100% import tariffs combined with massive subsidies e.g. 50%. On the open market FSLR is not viable, and cannot sell outside the US, and any change in policy will massively affect their margin including -ve margin. This is the real reason this stock is going down. You cannot put a price target on the stock as you do not know which government will get in next ( right now its a coin flip ) or what they will do with climate change, e.g. say it is a hoax or double down on it. Hence FSLR is not a viable company on its own due to even Europe making panels far cheaper than they. FSLR in principle can make panels very cheaply using the CdTe thin film tech on glass so I would suggest they get streamlined to get their costs to about 6c / W finished panels, then they can compete at an ASP of 10c. Certainly you cannot predict where this stock will go. Frankly I would say zero tariffs and zero VAT like in Europe to promote uptake of solar rather than 100% tariffs like in the US. Who cares who makes the panels or where? Its all automated.

Its just a momentum reallocation trade by institutions. 

When they run money they have to keep x% in energy. So when you get a war premium in oil with momentum theyll allocate away from one sub-sector to another. 

In this case its away from long-term investments in renewables that have fundamentally tailwinds like onshore tariffs and subsidies to short term speculative pickup like oil & gas.

Hope this helps. Its a temporary allocation within their constraints to pick up short term returns.

Short term directional trading at its best is very difficult. Short term directional trading options is tougher. You can trade 50,000, 100,00 shares on a dime or fifteen cents with stocks--that's the deal. Options... 30, 50, 100, contracts, scaling in an out all in a few hours, trading for small percentages. Have to be in and out before premium strip each and every day. You learn to take profits quickly. You could and should be all done for the day in about thirty minutes. You'll never catch the top 20% or the bottom 20%. It's super disciplined, and you have to stick to it, but still really tough. The great option traders wait for huge sell offs and scale in and get out when the V is done. Good luck. Better to buy a good stock and hold it. Or, like the movie "War Games," better to not have played at all. If you lose more than $10,000 trading options you should never trade options again!!!! You can learn a lot by just trading one option and scaling each day. Still, a losers game. At least wait for extreme volatility. The only way.
